Step 3. Visualise the results

Source: vignettes/a04_Visualise_results.Rmd
a04_Visualise_results.Rmd

Introduction

In this vignette we will explore the functionality and arguments of a set of functions that will help us to understand and visualise the results using a user-friendly set-up. In particular, we will delve into the following functions:

  • plotTemporalSymmetry(): to plot the temporal trend of the index and marker cohorts.
  • tableSequenceRatios(): to generate a gt table summarising the results.
  • plotSequenceRatio(): to plot the sequence ratios.

This function builds-up on previous functions, such as generateSequenceCohortSet() and summariseSequenceRatio() function (explained in detail in previous vignettes: Step 1. Generate a sequence cohort, and Step 2. Summarise sequence ratio). Hence, we will pick up the explanation from where we left off in the previous vignette.

# Load libraries
library(CDMConnector)
library(dplyr)
library(DBI)
library(CohortSymmetry)
library(duckdb)
library(DrugUtilisation)

# Connect to the database
db <- DBI::dbConnect(duckdb::duckdb(), 
                     dbdir = CDMConnector::eunomia_dir())
cdm <- cdm_from_con(
  con = db,
  cdm_schema = "main",
  write_schema = "main"
)

# Generate cohorts
cdm <- DrugUtilisation::generateIngredientCohortSet(
  cdm = cdm,
  name = "aspirin",
  ingredient = "aspirin")

cdm <- DrugUtilisation::generateIngredientCohortSet(
  cdm = cdm,
  name = "acetaminophen",
  ingredient = "acetaminophen")

# Generate a sequence cohort
cdm <- generateSequenceCohortSet(
  cdm = cdm,
  indexTable = "aspirin",
  markerTable = "acetaminophen",
  name = "intersect",
  combinationWindow = c(0,Inf))

# Calculate the sequence ratio
result <- summariseSequenceRatio(
  cohort = cdm$intersect
)

Plot the temporal trend of the index and marker cohorts
